results.title: A Touch of the terminals
results.creator_credit: Philip Bull and Australian Film Commission. Creative Development Branch
results.brief_description: Its the machine age, computers are taking over - reducing the workforce and increasing productivity. The unemployed can’t afford to buy the products produced and therefore the company can’t sell its products and is losing money. To make money they cull more workers, bring in more machines and again more unemployed who can’t afford to buy. A satirical look at the effects of computers. Cast includes Martin Vaughan, Michael Ross, Ray Anderson, Tony Llewellyn-Jones.

results.title: A Time for Bach
results.brief_description: By pictorial means the film attempts to integrate Bach’s music and its function today into the many varied and contradictory patterns of modern life.

results.title: A taste of China: cooking with Kenneth Lo
results.creator_credit: Eddie Joffe and Thames Video Collection
results.brief_description: Kenneth Lo, world famous Chinese chef and leading authority on Chinese food, is joined by actor Vincent Price on this Chinese cookery course. Chinese cuisine is one of the oldest in the world, with many contrasts in flavour, colour and texture. Kenneth Lo unlocks the secrets and mysteries of this cuisine and provides straightforward instructions for basic methods of preparing a Chinese family meal or elaborate banquet. Chefs from Lo’s cooking school appear on this video, preparing a range of delicious recipes.

results.title: A Tale of Till
results.brief_description: After briefly covering the Dark Ages and setting the scene in Germany, the film introduces Till Eulenspeigel and his place in German literature. The remainder of the film is then devoted to an outdoor puppet show of one of Till’s stories which is about the finding of purses filled with gold pieces.

results.title: A Taste of energy
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Colonial Sugar Industry and Scope Films
results.brief_description: The Australian sugar industry, showing all stages of cane cultivation and harvesting, extraction and refining of sugar. Impressions of life in the sugar producing regions of Queensland and northern New South Wales and the place of sugar in the Australian economy.

results.title: A Sufi tale
results.creator_credit: Gayle Thomas and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This animated film is based on an old Persian parable. The inhabitants of a village learn to overcome their fear of the unknown. The benefit of their new-found knowledge is demonstrated. The black-and-white images are reminiscent of German wood-cuts. No dialogue. Music by Normand Roger performed by Gropus 7. (Awards: Athens, USA; Espinho; Murcia.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gayle Thomas and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Study in wet
results.brief_description: There is no narration in this study of the many forms of water. A bright-colored surfboard is reflected in rippling water and the image returns as a kind of punctuation mark throughout the film. The abstract patterns of water and spray introduce other uses of water and the film ends in a climactic surfing sequence with experts riding giant waves.

results.title: A Streetcar named desire
results.creator_credit: John Erman, Marc Trabulus and Keith Barish Productions
results.brief_description: Blanche Dubois, a faded Southern belle whose fortunes have crumbled to nothing, comes to New Orleans to stay with her sister, Stella. Stella’s husband, the brutish but magnetic Stanley Kowalski is suspicious of her past and puts in train a devastating chain of events which will finally destroy for all time Blanche’s already tenuous grasp on the world of reality. Directed by John Erman for television, this version of “A Streetcar called desire” cannot help but invite comparisons to the 1954 Vivien Leigh/Marlon Brando version directed by Elia Kazan, which is the most famous adaptation of Tennessee Williams’ play. Nonetheless the three leads - Ann-Margaret, Treat Williams, Beverly D’Angelo - make a fine job of the material in a more realistic presentation of the play which goes to great lengths to establish the physical and moral decay of New Orleans in the 1940s. Also featuring Randy Quaid.
